messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
> On Tue, 4 Nov 2003, Jason wrote:
>
> > I've just recently started using junit and I've got a
> > quick question. I've created a series of tests using
> > a fixture which look (in form) like the following:
>
> Jargon Alert: a fixture is what you make assertions about. Usually
> the fixture is created in setUp() and tested in your testA(), testB(),
> etc.

Ah.. but in proper usage TestCase == fixture... so I have no argument
with his use of the word... assuming he's doing it "right" (i.e. his
TestCase is maximally cohesive)

> > Everything is working fine but now I've added a new
> > fixture and associated test cases which test a
> > different aspect of the system - call this class
> > 'TestAnotherThing.' I'd like to find some way to
> > launch swingui.TestRunner from a batch file and run
> > all the test cases from both classes but I can't
> > figure out how to make this happen. I'm sure it's
> > possible so what am I missing? Thanks in advance for
> > any help anyone can offer!
>
> Short answer: try using Ant. It allows you to specify tests using
> patterns, so that you can, for example, run all of the tests on your
> class path by writing

Bah!

Sure use Ant for your central builds, but it's useless overhead inside
the TDD cycle (if that's what you're doing.. if not then you should be).

Create a suite that contains the two (eventually more) TestCases.

BTW, you don't need the suite method in the TestCase. The framework
uses reflection to collect the tests, assuming the signatures are right.

You shoudl be using Eclipse if you aren't already... the JUnit plugin
makes many things easier.. including creating/maintaining custom suites.

Dave
